body_text.text: As highlighted by Nianguo Dong, Coronavirus-Disease of 2019 (COVID-19) can cause myocardial injury (1) . Putative mechanisms are acute coronary syndrome, demand ischemia, microvascular ischemic injury, cytokine dysregulation or myocarditis (2) . However, myocardial injury does not always correlate exclusively with COVID-19 and it may also reveal incidental cardiomyopathy. Thus, physician have to stay alert and a careful etiological assessment is required in these patients. As contagious risk and patient instability may preclude initial work up, reassessing the patient after the acute phase is of utmost importance.
To illustrate, we report an acute myocarditis with an underlying isolated ventricular non compaction (IVNC) in a COVID-19 patient with heart failure.

A 27-year-old male, without medical history, was admitted for respiratory distress, and diagnose with COVID-19. Hs-Troponin I and Nt-proBNP were elevated (100ng/L and 9300pg/ml) suggesting myocardial involvement. Bedside echocardiography revealed an enlarged left ventricle with impaired left ventricle ejection fraction (LVEF) of 20%. Patient improved on high dose diuretics and non-invasive ventilation. He was discharged 9 days later, on Bisoprolol, Furosemide and Spironolactone. One month later, LVEF improved at 40% with normal filling pressure and cardiac output. Echocardiography revealed a two layered structure of the myocardium suggesting IVNC(3). CMR confirmed the IVNC diagnosis but also revealed an acute myocarditis (figure1). Coronary-CT angiography ruledout coronary artery disease. IVNC patients have variable prognosis, ranging from prolonged asymptomatic course to severe cardiac disability. Prognosis is worse in patients hospitalized for heart failure, NYHA classes III-IV, lower LVEF and elevated LV filling pressures(4).
In this case, reassessing the patient after the COVID-19 acute phase allowed us to diagnose an underlying severe IVNC and subsequently initiate appropriate treatment and follow-up.

FIGREF0.text: Multi-modality imaging of ventricular non compaction (IVNC) and myocarditis 1. Cardiac Magnetic Resonance (CMR). Four-chamber (1A,C) and middle short-axis (1B,D) views. Sub-epicardial late gadolinium enhancement in cine T2/T1-weighted images suggesting acute myocarditis (white circle). Double layered myocardium with a thin compacted epicardial layer (white line) and a thicker non compacted endocardial band (double arrows) consisting of trabecular recesses suggesting IVNC. 2. Transthoracic-echocardiography. 2A-B: Non compacted endocardial layer (double white-arrows) and compacted layer (white lines); 2C: Trabecular recesses deeply perfused in color doppler (white-arrows). 3. Electrocardiogram. Sinus tachycardia, Q-wave and T-wave inversion in V1-V3 leads, left axis deviation. 4. Chest X-ray. Bilateral consolidation and significant heart enlargement.
